comment.shortText:
Create a new instance of Botkit to define the controller for a conversational app.
To connect Botkit to a chat platform, pass in a fully configured `adapter`.
If one is not specified, Botkit will expose an adapter for the Microsoft Bot Framework.

Create a new Botkit instance and optionally specify a platform-specific adapter.
By default, Botkit will create a [BotFrameworkAdapter](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/javascript/api/botbuilder/botframeworkadapter?view=botbuilder-ts-latest).

Create a new Botkit instance and optionally specify a platform-specific adapter.
By default, Botkit will create a [BotFrameworkAdapter](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/javascript/api/botbuilder/botframeworkadapter?view=botbuilder-ts-latest).
Configuration for this instance of Botkit
The path of the main Botkit SDK, used to generate relative paths
Any BotBuilder-compatible adapter - defaults to a [BotFrameworkAdapter](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/javascript/api/botbuilder/botframeworkadapter?view=botbuilder-ts-latest)
A BotBuilder DialogSet that serves as the top level dialog container for the Botkit app
A direct reference to the underlying HTTP server object
a BotBuilder storage driver - defaults to MemoryStorage
The current version of Botkit Core
An Express webserver

(For use by Botkit plugins only) - Add a dependency to Botkit's bootup process that must be marked as completed using `completeDep()`.
Botkit's `controller.ready()` function will not fire until all dependencies have been marked complete.

comment.shortText:
Convert a local path from a plugin folder to a full path relative to the webserver's main views folder.
Allows a plugin to bundle views/layouts and make them available to the webserver's renderer.

comment.text: something like path.join(__dirname,'views')

comment.shortText:
Accepts the result of a BotBuilder adapter's `processActivity()` method and processes it into a Botkit-style message and BotWorker instance
which is then used to test for triggers and emit events.
NOTE: This method should only be used in custom adapters that receive messages through mechanisms other than the main webhook endpoint (such as those received via websocket, for example)

comment.text: a TurnContext representing an incoming message, typically created by an adapter's `processActivity()` method.

comment.shortText:
Instruct your bot to listen for a pattern, and do something when that pattern is heard.
Patterns will be "heard" only if the message is not already handled by an in-progress dialog.
To "hear" patterns _before_ dialogs are processed, use `controller.interrupts()` instead.

comment.text: One or more string, regular expression, or test function
A list of event types that should be evaluated for the given patterns
a function that will be called should the pattern be matched

comment.shortText:
Instruct your bot to listen for a pattern, and do something when that pattern is heard.
Interruptions work just like "hears" triggers, but fire _before_ the dialog system is engaged,
and thus handlers will interrupt the normal flow of messages through the processing pipeline.

comment.text: One or more string, regular expression, or test function
A list of event types that should be evaluated for the given patterns
a function that will be called should the pattern be matched

comment.shortText:
Use `controller.ready()` to wrap any calls that require components loaded during the bootup process.
This will ensure that the calls will not be made until all of the components have successfully been initialized.

comment.text: A function to run when Botkit is booted and ready to run.

comment.shortText:
Save the current conversation state pertaining to a given BotWorker's activities.
Note: this is normally called internally and is only required when state changes happen outside of the normal processing flow.

comment.text: a BotWorker instance created using `controller.spawn()`

comment.shortText:
Shutdown the webserver and prepare to terminate the app.
Causes Botkit to first emit a special `shutdown` event, process any bound handlers, and then finally terminate the webserver.
Bind any necessary cleanup helpers to the shutdown event - for example, close the connection to mongo.

Create a platform-specific BotWorker instance that can be used to respond to messages or generate new outbound messages.
The spawned `bot` contains all information required to process outbound messages and handle dialog state, and may also contain extensions
for handling platform-specific events or activities.

comment.text: Preferably receives a DialogContext, though can also receive a TurnContext. If excluded, must call `bot.changeContext(reference)` before calling any other method.

comment.shortText:
Trigger an event to be fired.  This will cause any bound handlers to be executed.
Note: This is normally used internally, but can be used to emit custom events.

This class extends the [BotFrameworkAdapter](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/javascript/api/botbuilder/botframeworkadapter?view=botbuilder-ts-latest) with a few additional features to support Microsoft Teams.
* Changes userAgent to reflect Botkit instead of BotBuilder
* Adds getChannels() (MS Teams)
* Adds middleware for adjusting location of tenant id field (MS Teams)

Get the list of channels in a MS Teams team.
Can only be called with a TurnContext that originated in a team conversation - 1:1 conversations happen _outside a team_ and thus do not contain the required information to call this API.
comment.returns: an array of channels in the format [{name: string, id: string}]

comment.text: A TurnContext object representing a message or event from a user in Teams

and [startConversationWithUser()](../reference/facebook.md#startconversationwithuser) (Facebook Messenger).
Be sure to check the platform documentation for others - most adapters include at least one.

An extension on the [BotBuilder Dialog Class](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/javascript/api/botbuilder-dialogs/dialog?view=botbuilder-ts-latest) that provides a Botkit-friendly interface for
defining and interacting with multi-message dialogs. Dialogs can be constructed using `say()`, `ask()` and other helper methods.
Create a new BotkitConversation object
Create a new BotkitConversation object
A unique identifier for this dialog, used to later trigger this dialog
A pointer to the main Botkit controller
A map of every message in the dialog, broken into threads
An an action to the conversation timeline. This can be used to go to switch threads or end the dialog.
comment.text:
When provided the name of another thread in the conversation, this will cause the bot to go immediately
to that thread.

Otherwise, use one of the following keywords:
* `stop`
* `repeat`
* `complete`
* `timeout`

[Learn more about building conversations →](../conversations.md#build-a-conversation)

```javascript

// go to a thread called "next_thread"
convo.addAction('next_thread');

// end the conversation and mark as successful
convo.addAction('complete');
```
An action or thread name
The name of the thread to which this action is added.  Defaults to `default`

comment.shortText:
Cause the dialog to call a child dialog, wait for it to complete,
then store the results in a variable and resume the parent dialog.
Use this to [combine multiple dialogs into bigger interactions.](../conversations.md#composing-dialogs)

comment.text: the id of another dialog
the variable name in which to store the results of the child dialog. if not provided, defaults to dialog_id.
the name of a thread to which this call should be added. defaults to 'default'

comment.shortText:
Cause the current dialog to handoff to another dialog.
The parent dialog will not resume when the child dialog completes. However, the afterDialog event will not fire for the parent dialog until all child dialogs complete.
Use this to [combine multiple dialogs into bigger interactions.](../conversations.md#composing-dialogs)

comment.text: the id of another dialog
the name of a thread to which this call should be added. defaults to 'default'

comment.shortText:
Add a message template to a specific thread.
Messages added with `say()` and `addMessage()` will be sent one after another without a pause.

comment.text: Message template to be sent
Name of thread to which message will be added

comment.shortText: Identical to [ask()](#ask), but accepts the name of a thread to which the question is added.
comment.text: [Learn more about building conversations →](../conversations.md#build-a-conversation)
A message that will be used as the prompt
One or more handler functions defining possible conditional actions based on the response to the question
Name of variable to store response in.
Name of thread to which message will be added

comment.shortText:
Bind a function to run after the dialog has completed.
The first parameter to the handler will include a hash of all variables set and values collected from the user during the conversation.
The second parameter to the handler is a BotWorker object that can be used to start new dialogs or take other actions.

comment.text: in the form async(results, bot) { ... }

comment.shortText:
Add a question to the default thread.
In addition to a message template, receives either a single handler function to call when an answer is provided,
or an array of handlers paired with trigger patterns. When providing multiple conditions to test, developers may also provide a
handler marked as the default choice.

comment.text: a message that will be used as the prompt
one or more handler functions defining possible conditional actions based on the response to the question.
name of variable to store response in.

comment.shortText:
Register a handler function that will fire before a given thread begins.
Use this hook to set variables, call APIs, or change the flow of the conversation using `convo.gotoThread`

comment.text: A valid thread defined in this conversation
A handler function in the form async(convo, bot) => { ... }

comment.shortText: Bind a function to run whenever a user answers a specific question.  Can be used to validate input and take conditional actions.

comment.text: name of the variable to watch for changes
a handler function that will fire whenever a user's response is used to change the value of the watched variable

comment.shortText:
Add a non-interactive message to the default thread.
Messages added with `say()` and `addMessage()` will _not_ wait for a response, will be sent one after another without a pause.

comment.text: Message template to be sent

comment.shortText: A map of every message in the dialog, broken into threads

comment.shortText:
Get a Slack API client with the correct credentials based on the team identified in the incoming activity.
This is used by many internal functions to get access to the Slack API, and is exposed as `bot.api` on any bot worker instances.

comment.text: An incoming message activity

comment.shortText:
Get the bot user id associated with the team on which an incoming activity originated. This is used internally by the SlackMessageTypeMiddleware to identify direct_mention and mention events.
In single-team mode, this will pull the information from the Slack API at launch.
In multi-team mode, this will use the `getBotUserByTeam` method passed to the constructor to pull the information from a developer-defined source.

comment.text: An incoming message activity

This interface defines the options that can be passed into the SlackAdapter constructor function.
A token (provided by Slack) for a bot to work on a single workspace
The oauth client id provided by Slack for multi-team apps
The oauth client secret provided by Slack for multi-team apps
A token used to validate that incoming webhooks originated with Slack.

comment.shortText:
Allow the adapter to startup without a complete configuration.
This is risky as it may result in a non-functioning or insecure adapter.
This should only be used when getting started.

Parameters passed to the [Google API client library](https://www.npmjs.com/package/googleapis) which is in turn used to send messages.
Define credentials per [the GoogleAuthOptions defined here](https://github.com/googleapis/google-auth-library-nodejs/blob/master/src/auth/googleauth.ts#L54),
OR, specify GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS in environment [as described in the Google docs](https://cloud.google.com/docs/authentication/getting-started).

Shared secret token used to validate the origin of incoming webhooks.
Get this from the [Google API console for your bot app](https://console.cloud.google.com/apis/api/chat.googleapis.com/hangouts-chat) - it is found on the Configuration tab under the heading "Verification Token".
If defined, the origin of all incoming webhooks will be validated and any non-matching requests will be rejected.

Create an adapter to handle incoming messages from Facebook and translate them into a standard format for processing by your bot.
Configuration options

This is a specialized version of [Botkit's core BotWorker class](core.md#BotWorker) that includes additional methods for interacting with Facebook.
It includes all functionality from the base class, as well as the extension methods below.
comment.text: When using the FacebookAdapter with Botkit, all `bot` objects passed to handler functions will include these extensions.

comment.shortText: Reserved for use internally by Botkit's `controller.spawn()`, this class is used to create a BotWorker instance that can send messages, replies, and make other API calls.
comment.text:
When used with the FacebookAdapter's multi-tenancy mode, it is possible to spawn a bot instance by passing in the Facebook page ID representing the appropriate bot identity.
Use this in concert with [startConversationWithUser()](#startConversationWithUser) and [changeContext()](core.md#changecontext) to start conversations
or send proactive alerts to users on a schedule or in response to external events.

```javascript
let bot = await controller.spawn(FACEBOOK_PAGE_ID);
```

A simple API client for the Facebook API.  Automatically signs requests with the access token and app secret proof.
It can be used to call any API provided by Facebook.
a page access token
an app secret

optional api version used when constructing api calls, defaults to v3.2

This adapter middleware, when used in conjunction with FacebookAdapter and Botkit, will result in Botkit emitting events with
names based on their event type.
This interface defines the options that can be passed into the FacebookAdapter constructor function.
When bound to a single page, use `access_token` to specify the "page access token" provided in the Facebook developer portal's "Access Tokens" widget of the "Messenger Settings" page.
Alternate root url used to contruct calls to Facebook's API.  Defaults to 'graph.facebook.com' but can be changed (for mocking, proxy, etc).
Alternate API version used to construct calls to Facebook's API. Defaults to v3.2
The "app secret" from the "basic settings" page from your app's configuration in the Facebook developer portal

Allow the adapter to startup without a complete configuration.
This is risky as it may result in a non-functioning or insecure adapter.
This should only be used when getting started.
When bound to multiple teams, provide a function that, given a page id, will return the page access token for that page.
The "verify token" used to initially create and verify the Webhooks subscription settings on Facebook's developer portal.

A plugin for Botkit that provides access to an instance of [Botkit CMS](https://github.com/howdyai/botkit-cms), including the ability to load script content into a DialogSet
and bind before, after and onChange handlers to those dynamically imported dialogs by name.
Botkit Plugin name

Bind a handler function that will fire after a given dialog ends.
Provides a way to use BotkitConversation.after() on dialogs loaded dynamically via the CMS api instead of being created in code.

comment.text: The name of the script to bind to
A handler function in the form async(results, bot) => {}

comment.shortText:
Bind a handler function that will fire before a given script and thread begin.
Provides a way to use BotkitConversation.before() on dialogs loaded dynamically via the CMS api instead of being created in code.

comment.text: The name of the script to bind to
The name of a thread within the script to bind to
A handler function in the form async(convo, bot) => {}

comment.shortText:
Botkit plugin init function
Autoloads all scripts into the controller's main dialogSet.

comment.text: A Botkit controller object

comment.shortText: Load all script content from the configured CMS instance into a DialogSet and prepare them to be used.

Bind a handler function that will fire when a given variable is set within a a given script.
Provides a way to use BotkitConversation.onChange() on dialogs loaded dynamically via the CMS api instead of being created in code.

comment.text: The name of the script to bind to
The name of a variable within the script to bind to
A handler function in the form async(value, convo, bot) => {}

comment.shortText:
Uses the Botkit CMS trigger API to test an incoming message against a list of predefined triggers.
If a trigger is matched, the appropriate dialog will begin immediately.
comment.returns: Returns false if a dialog is NOT triggered, otherwise returns void.

comment.text: The current bot worker instance
An incoming message to be interpretted
